title: The Four Purusharthas - Goals of Human Life
description: The four legitimate aims that give meaning to human existence

goals.name: Dharma (धर्म)
goals.description: Living according to moral law and cosmic order
goals.importance: Foundation for all other goals. Without dharma, other pursuits lead to suffering.
how_to_pursue: Study scriptures and learn ethical principles
Fulfill your duties according to your stage of life
Act with integrity in all situations
goals.vashishta_teaching: Dharma is not a burden but the path to true freedom. When you live righteously, the universe supports you.

goals.name: Artha (अर्थ)
goals.description: Earning livelihood and creating material wellbeing through righteous means
goals.importance: Necessary for survival and supporting family. But must be earned ethically.
how_to_pursue: Save and invest wisely for future security
goals.vashishta_teaching: Wealth earned through dharma brings peace; wealth earned through adharma brings anxiety. The truly wealthy person is content with enough.

goals.name: Kama (काम)
goals.description: Legitimate enjoyment of life's pleasures within dharmic boundaries
goals.importance: Life is meant to be enjoyed. Denying natural desires creates suppression. But enjoyment must be balanced.
how_to_pursue: Respect boundaries of dharma in relationships
Appreciate beauty in nature, art, music
Cultivate refined tastes and aesthetic sense
goals.vashishta_teaching: Pleasure pursued with awareness becomes a spiritual practice. Pleasure pursued with greed becomes bondage. The wise enjoy without being enslaved.

goals.name: Moksha (मोक्ष)
goals.description: Ultimate goal - freedom from the cycle of birth and death, union with the Divine
goals.importance: The highest aim. All other goals ultimately serve this purpose.
how_to_pursue: Realize your true nature beyond body-mind
Live in awareness of the Divine in all
goals.vashishta_teaching: Moksha is not somewhere to reach - it is what you already are. Remove ignorance, and liberation shines forth naturally.

balance_teaching: The Four Purusharthas must be balanced. Pursue artha and kama within dharma, and let all three lead you toward moksha. This is the art of dharmic living.
